adjectives.description: rooted (comparative more rooted, superlative most rooted)

entries.meaning: Having roots, or certain type of roots.
Fixed in one position; immobile; unable to move.
(figuratively) Ingrained, as through repeated use; entrenched; habitual or instinctive.
examples: He will immediately break in on their moſt rooted prejudices ; and with a kind of malignant ſatisfaction hack their darling notions with unſparing rigour and unbluſhing inſolence.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, usually with "in") Having a basic or fundamental connection (to a thing); based, originating (from).
examples: Proper Philadelphians, especially before they became Episcopalians, and the unfashionable branches of their families to this day are surely more rooted in Westtown than St. Paul′s, the fashionable favorite.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, graph theory, of a tree or graph) Having a root.
(slang) In trouble or in strife, screwed.
examples: I am absolutely rooted if Ferris finds out about this

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) Broken, damaged, non-functional.
examples: I'm going to have to call a mechanic, my car's rooted.

entries.meaning: (computing, not comparable) Having a root (superuser) account that has been compromised.
examples: You are rooted. All your base are belong to us.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of root
